productDescription: The EOS Rebel T6 camera can be ideal for anyone looking to step up their imaging game. Equipped with an 18.0 Megapixel CMOS image sensor and many automatic and creative options, the EOS Rebel T6 is easy to use, simple to share wirelessly with and delivers impressive image quality to your audience.
Brilliantly clear and colorful images are at hand with the 18.0 Megapixel (APS-C) CMOS sensor and powerful DIGIC 4+ Image Processor, even in low light thanks to the camera’s wide ISO of 100–6400.
Built-in Wi-Fi* and NFC** capability allows for easy uploading to social media sites, remote shooting through the free Canon Camera Connect app*, image transfer to compatible devices and more.
The Optical Viewfinder allows quick, accurate focusing by firmly framing and capturing your subject.

Record Full HD video with superb quality and beautiful background blur, even under low-light conditions. The EOS Rebel T6 is compatible with all EF/EF-S lenses to help you realize the “movie director” in you. Try different lenses for fun and new perspectives.
For more creative shooting, simply twist the Mode Dial to try out modes like Portrait and Landscape.

reviews.reviewTitle: A perfect Beginner's DSLR in a small and lightweight body
reviews.reviewText:
BUILD QUALITY

To start off this review, let’s first take a look at the build quality of this lens.
The first thing you’re going to notice is just how small this camera is for a dslr. The T6 is one of the smallest DSLR’s you can buy from Canon and pretty much any company for that matter.
But to me, that’s not a bad thing. Being a very lightweight camera can sometimes mean you’re more inclined to pick it up and take it out with you, rather than being worried that’s it’s going to be too heavy.

On the top of the camera right here we’ve got all of the buttons that’ you’d expect to see on a beginner dslr and also this mode dial which allows you to select the mode you want to be in.

Of course you’ve got all of the basic beginner modes, like sports and portraits etc, but also aperture, shutter and manual modes for when you want to get a little bit more advanced.

The buttons on the back are actually pretty nice. I would have preferred to have had the menu and display button on the top however as I use them pretty often.

So overall the camera’s build is good for what it is, a lightweight dslr, but i’d always be a little bit careful with this type of body.

Oh and guys if you want to see some sample images I’ve taken with the Canon t6, i’ll put a link in the description box below under this video and you can check them out.

LCD SCREEN

So let’s turn this camera around now and talk about the screen.

We’ve got a 3 inch screen on the back which has 920,000 dots and after testing it out for a while, it actually looks pretty good.

Even in bright daylight it was actually pretty easy to see.

It is however missing something that I really do like to see and that’s an articulating screen.

Whereas on cameras like the Canon t6i and t6s, you can swivel your screen around to get better composition, with the t6 your kind of forced to take the photo even if you can’t see the screen.

And that’s a bit of a pity to me and something I would have liked to have seen. I also would have liked to have seen a touch screen on the back of this camera, because they’re especially good for beginners.

The screen itself is actually pretty nice, but i’d like to see those improvements made in the next camera.

MENUS

So let’s quickly talk about the menus on the T6.

If you’ve ever used a Canon camera before you’ll feel right at home with the menu system. It’s incredible easy to get around and change the settings you need.

A little tip is that if you switch the dial on the top to manual mode, you’ll get a lot more settings that you can change which can be great.

Again it would have been nice to have a touch screen to make it quicker to change the settings not eh fly, but this little d pad right here isn’t too bad and it’s pretty responsvie.

So overall the menus are good, but make sure to check out more of the fearless in manual mode.

WIFI & NFC

So one of the new inclusions to the Canon T6 is wifi & nfc.

So essentially what this allows you to do is connect your camera to your phone and do a number of things like transfer your photos and also get a live view of what your shooting.

To me this is the perfect camera to have this feature, because it’s targeting a younger generation of users who love to share their photos on instagram and Facebook.

It was pretty easy to setup the wifi, but not as intuitive as the 80d that i tested a few weeks ago.

BURST MODE & AUTOFOCUS

So let’s talk about the burst mode of the Canon T6.

So essentially what this means is how fast the camera can take photos in a row per second.

The Canon T6 isn’t super quick and can only shoot 3 shots per second.

Now most of the time when you take a photo you’ll only be taking one shot anyway so it won’t make a big difference, but if you want to take some photos at a sports game or of a bird, this might not be the best camera for you.

Autofocus in stills mode is actually surprisingly good, it’s snappy and should be fast enough for most situations. Now the lens that comes with the camera isn’t great, and is noisy in autofocus, but if you can get passed the noise, which sounds bit like a bee, it’ll work pretty well in well lit situations.

VIDEO

So let’s talk about using this camera for video.

It’s pretty basic for video and will be fine for day to day videos.

Unfortunately though the autofocus in video isn’t great.

The lens that comes in the kit with the t6 isn’t an stm lens, which means it’s not going to have smooth and responsive af in video mode.

My tip would be to switch it over to manual focus o the lens and then just shoot like that.

One thing howver though which was good to see is that we have full manual control over our video and audio settings.

Where as on some older rebel cameras, you could only shoot in auto mode, the t6 does allow to have some manual control. We are missing a microphone jack though unfortunately, so if you are in need of some better audio, I might advise looking at the t6i and t6s.

PRICE & VALUE FOR MONEY

So let’s talk about price and more importantly value for money.

Now the T6 comes in at $549, which is one of the cheapest DSLR’s you can buy on the market today.

You also get a lens with that so all you need to get up and running after that is an sd card and you’re good.

To me it’s not a bad price, but there are definitely some very competitive options that I might look at, for example if you pay just a few hundred dollars more you can get a Canon t6i which is very good camera.

-

So overall the Canon t6 isn’t a bad little camera, and for beginners, it’ll be a lot of fun to learn on. If you’ve never owned a dslr this is a good camera to learn on, but if you want to go a little further with your dslr, I’d definitely be looking at a camera like the Canon t6i or t6s.

reviews.reviewTitle: A great camera with many features
reviews.reviewText:
I'm a semi-pro photographer. I have a full frame camera that I use for professional shoots which I love dearly, however I wanted an "everyday" camera that I could take everywhere and not be devastated if it gets stolen/broken. Also, I wanted a camera that I could hand off to someone else (like my son or husband) without fear and one that they will actually be able to use. This camera fit the bill perfectly! So a few questions you might have:

Should I get the T6 or T5?

They are basically the same camera. The only difference is that the T6 has wi-fi and has a Digic 4+ processor whereas the T5 has just the basic Digic 4 and no wi-fi. To me, the wi-fi was not a feature that I would use at all. I take so many photos that transferring them over wi-fi would be a joke. However, the fact that the Digic 4+ is faster and better was what prompted me to go with the T6. Plus, the screen in the back has a better resolution. However, if these features are not a big deal to you, the T5 does present a huge savings and it's basically the same camera.

Does it come with software?

Yes. But for some reason they didn't include it in the box, nor do they really mention it prominently in the instruction book that comes with it. The software is Canon's Digital Photo Professional (DPP) which is a raw image processor. It comes with a bunch of other software as well and they're pretty powerful/useful. You have to go on the Canon's website to download all this.

Does it come with a manual?

You would think the answer is an obvious "yes" but actually, no. It comes with a quick start guide that tells you how to use most of the automatic features and how to get started. The guide is great for beginners as it really breaks things down to basics. But you do not get the full camera manual. You have to download that from Canon's web site. (Which is a shame)

Should I get this camera?

I think if you're a beginner and want to explore photography, you can't go wrong with this. There are so many guided automatic modes that gently help you and the photos from these auto features actually come out really well. There's full automatic where the camera does everything, to semi-automatic where you control several things but the camera does the rest. There is shutter and aperture priority where you want to control most things but still need a helper for aperture or shutter speed. And then there is full manual for when you feel ready to control all things the camera is capable of.

When I'm ready to upgrade, what is the next step?

The next step to is to get the 50mm 1.8 lens. This will enable you to work with lower available light and give you some awesome background blur. And it's probably the most affordable lens you can possibly buy.

All around great camera for a beginner, enthusiasts, or a pro who needs something smaller and lightweight.

reviews.reviewTitle: There is no way to change the ISO
reviews.reviewText: The ratings on this camera say that the ISO goes up very high, which is true. However, what they don't tell you is that the ISO is Automatic and there is no way to set it yourself in Manuel Mode. You can change the aperture and Shutter speed but it will automatically choose your ISO. Not a fan of that! Besides that the came is very user friendly and the wifi works great!

The Canon EOS Rebel T6 is a great started DSLR, I've owned it for about a year and only have two complaints. First of all I wish the screen would flip out. It does not flip out or move at all but If you're fine with a fixed screen this is in my opinion is a great entry level DSLR. The only other problem I have with this camera is that there is no microphone jack. I bought the "videomic go" from Rode without thinking about it and when I went to put it on my camera I was super disappointed that there wasn't a mic jack. Other than those two minor inconveniences I love this camera!

reviews.reviewTitle: Good, solid camera with some disappointments too.
reviews.reviewText:
I'm mostly a novice photographer with a specific interest: product photography for wood turnings I make and sell online. I purchased this camera after a couple of other failed attempts and overall, I'm pleased.

This is a basic camera and lens combo kit and if you're looking for some bells and whistles like an articulated LCD display, this isn't for you. However, the photos are outstanding, it has both a wide range of automatic settings as well as convenient access to more advanced controls if you want to set your own shutter speed, aperture, manual focus and so on.

It is comfortable to hold, but I have mine tripod mounted all the time.

Build quality is good and comparable to the Sony A3000 and the Nikon that I bought earlier. I do prefer this camera over these others, although I will say that the Nikon LCD interface is very intuitive. Having said that, it's basically what all low-end DSLRs are these days: plastic. That's not a bad thing, and it makes for a nice, lightweight camera if you're out in the field shooting. Likewise, the lens is also plastic and with a plastic mount so if you want something heavier you're better off with a bare camera and a separate lens.

The LCD screen on this camera is of decent but not huge size. Still, it is fine for displaying settings. In Live View mode it's pretty good in my "studio" but I can't comment on contrast and visibility outdoors. However, it is clear, seems to have a fine resolution and does the job. However, it isn't articulated like some people prefer so that may be a deal-breaker for you. For me, not so much.

Software:

On-camera is good. It also has a "feature guide" that helps you along if you want to stray from the automatic settings. For example, you can change to aperture priority mode and it guides you through other settings. Very helpful for a newbie like me.

Bundled is non-existent. I went to the Canon site and downloaded a set of utilities (this camera is also known as the 1300D). Included are a sort of Lightroom clone, another editor that I haven't even loaded, and a tethered shooting utility that I use. A lot.

So for some reason Canon doesn't provide any software with the product, and not even a manual. That's mystifying to me but can all be found online. I got the manual and the utilities above. By the way, Canon is really aggravating about how you download software. Once you find it and choose to download, be prepared to provide your body serial number in order to link to the download. Sheesh!

The main thing I wanted was to be able to shoot tethered to my computer, and, since I've been using Photoshop forever, I also use Lightroom (and also Gimp and UFraw for those of you who know what those are :-)

So how is that going? Pretty well. However, you have to have a tethering cable and Canon will sell you a cable for twenty-five bucks, or you can get this: "IFC-500U Compatible USB Cable" right here on Amazon for $8.

Shooting tethered is great for me, because as I age, my vision is getting worse. I can now shoot products from my computer and use a 22" monitor as a live view screen and then take the shot without touching the camera (after I've turned it on).

Looking back, had I realized then what I now do, I'd have bought the T5 instead. Why? It's $100 cheaper, and really what I got for the difference is a slightly faster processor (don't need it), a better LCD screen (that I don't use), and WiFi (which sucks on this camera. Big time).

Why do I say the WiFi sucks? Well because it isn't really compatible with a standard computer OS. You can shoot and dump off to a phone or an iPad but really, not to a computer? So my hope was to fire up the camera, have it seen as another resource on my home network, and move the photos to my 2TB NAS. However, the camera will not work in WiFi if a cable is attached, and vice versa. Which really is rendered moot anyway by the fact that it doesn't work with a PC or a Mac OS. C'mon, Man!

How many photographers spend hundreds of dollars on a camera to put photos on their phone? I mean, you can just use your phone for that.

Hence the three stars. YMMV

The Canon Rebel T6 is also known as the 1300D throughout the world. Without getting too technical, this model is a great entry level camera for novice photographers to learn the art of photography. The two lenses that are included provide the ability to take desirable photos near and far. It would be useful for anyone ordering this camera to remember lens filters, in order to protect the lenses from debris and damage. You will need a few memory cards and extra batteries are always useful. The wifi feature means easy uploading to your smartphone for social media posting or sending via e-mail. I have used the Canon Rebel series in the past and have had good luck with the model.

reviews.reviewTitle: Awesome camera for someone new to photography
reviews.reviewText:
I am brand spanking new to photography and DSLR cameras. Thanks to a few hours at the University of YouTube, I think I have the hang of it. So my review is partial, but from the perspective of a total novice to photography and something other than a point and shoot camera.

Feature guide
I'm putting this first as this may be the most amazing and useful component of this camera for a complete newbie and the #1 reason this is an AWESOME camera for someone getting into photography. Since I didn't want to use my camera on auto mode (I could stick with a Coolpix if that's what I was looking for) and my goal was to learn how to use a DSLR in manual mode, the feature guide has been vital in helping me learn quickly. When changing modes (manual, aperture priority, Quick Control, etc), a brief description of the mode will pop up on the LCD. This is SUPER useful for a complete novice that has nearly ZERO knowledge (Thank You YouTube!) of what the different modes/controls are supposed to do. Seriously - best.feature.ever! For those that already know all of this like the back of their hand (I deeply admire you!), you can turn this feature off so it doesn't annoy you.

Camera body
This is a heavy piece of equipment compared to the slim, simple point and shoot cameras (read: Nikon Coolpix). However, it is fairly comfortable to hold. The body has a nice curvature in the front with a rubbery grip which helps to keep it from slipping in my hand - for all I know, they all have this but again, I have little to compare it to. My son has a Canon EOS 30D (released in 2000?) and I can say that this model is significantly lighter than his.

Lenses
I did some research on lenses and boy are these puppies expensive! I appreciate having both the 18-55mm and 75-300mm lenses with this kit. As a beginner, this will allow you to get all the basic pictures you could hope for all at once. I can take close up pictures and landscape pictures (the pictures I have included here were all taken with the lenses that came in this kit on my first few weeks using this camera). I'm sure there are much better lenses out there that come with a hefty price tag but for a beginner, this kit will give you everything you need to get started and take some pretty decent pictures.

LCD monitor
The picture on the monitor is pretty clear and I used this a lot my first couple days. Instead of looking through the eye piece, I used the LCD display to shoot my pictures. As I became more familiar with the various ISO, F/S, and shutter speed settings, I switched up to shooting using the eye piece and used the display to quickly see/adjust my manual settings.

Picture quality
I'm pretty impressed. The pictures come out clear and sharp (assuming its correctly focused when on manual focus). The colors are bold and vibrant in my opinion. I don't think the pictures of my kids have ever turned out so good. Side note: I did start using the auto focus feature recently while on a road trip to be able to shoot faster and I am very please with how well the pictures turned out. It was quick to focus and will likely be using this feature often when I am out and about (with little time to set up the shot).

I am incredibly happy with my purchase and if I had to do over again, I would pick this model. After purchasing this camera, I purchased a used Canon 30D for my son as he wanted to learn as well. In comparison, the Canon EOS has come a long way in terms of design, ease of use for a beginner, and features but if anything, I know based on having both a new and used (old) camera in the house now, that they can stand the test of time if cared for properly. Oh, and having a bag in the kit is also pretty handy.
great Camera for everyday use!

Love it. I haven't taken pictures in a while. I have a 35mm Canon AE-1 camera that I've been using since the early 80's. I use digital but mostly with an IPhone. This is my big move to DSLR.
The price was reasonable, due to the fact that the T6 is mostly plastic. There is a lot to get familiar with but having fun in the process.
Good deal, good buy. Getting back into an old hobby. Loving it

Great option for beginners. Takes excellent pictures and like most DSLR cameras, it gives a lot of room for editing and post-processing (just make sure you're shooting in raw, not jpeg). Would recommend getting a prime lens to go with this if on a tight budget.

When I opened the package I see this product is used and I felt like returning it back but I need it for my vacation.
Lenses is not properly covered with bubble wrap.
The worst part is the neck band is also missing some rubber lockers.
Love that I can use the camera connect app to operate the camera and view photos on my phone instantly. Took a few tries to figure it out, but it works.

I have owned Canon cameras all my life, and recently treated myself to this one. This camera is so easy to use, it features a large information screen with setting tips that make your shots effortless. A great camera for a beginning photographer. The quality of the images are fabulous, the ease of changing settings, lightweight, fits in the hand and just takes great pictures.

If I had one complaint it was the video settings... these were a bit difficult to find, and I had to practice a few times, so taking videos was a touch more difficult.

Love the fact that the lenses and filters from my old camera (yes, the one that used film) work on this camera.

The ability to upload using wi-fi is also a plus - long battery life, and the mobile/computer apps are quite robust.

reviews.reviewTitle: Even getting great shots of the moon
reviews.reviewText: I've been using it constantly. Even getting great shots of the moon.

I love my new T6 - it's everything I've ever wanted. The body weight is just right to where I can have it dangling around my neck all day and my neck isn't sore. The details it picks up is incredible! My black pug is very difficult to photograph but this camera is able to do it with ease! I love it and highly recommend it's a purchase you won't regret!

reviews.reviewTitle: Awesome entry level set up for the burgeoning "Serious" photog.
reviews.reviewText: Perfect intro level DSLR. Plenty of awesome source material out there to get going and get shooting. Tons of instructional videos on YouTube for free so no need to waste money on classes if there is a particular area of skill you want to "focus" on - sorry lol! Awesome quality given the brand and a veritable trove of accessories and lenses to pick from when you want to up your game. Remember it's not about the equipment at the end of the day, it's all about your own skill and know-how as a photographer. You could have the most expensive, mirrorless, digital, precision wrought camera in all the world that would still take shoddy photos if ones skill level was low. This camera is a perfect entry level to stepping up your game as a serious photog, as a youtube content creator and a plethora of other creative endeavours. If you're new to this type of camera set up the initial learning curve might feel a bit tough but its very adaptive and super easy to navigate once you do. One piece of advice would be this: buy and extra battery so you always have one on charge ready to pop since waiting around for a single rechargeable power pack to be ready will totally wreck your stride and other field testing, it sucks to have to cut short a really good project simply because you ran out of juice.

reviews.reviewTitle: It is a good camera to start in the world of photography
reviews.reviewText:
It is a good camera to start in the world of photography.
It is not a good camera to start vlogging. The video autofocus is not good.

reviews.reviewTitle: I love mine. I've now had it over a year.
reviews.reviewText:
I got mine with the kit lens,...which I promptly damaged. I ended up buying a better telephoto for only a little more than I read it would cost to repair the old one, (hey, I'm the one who dropped it, I wasn't expecting it to be under warranty.)
I have used it to take pictures of both fireworks and a lunar eclipse. Granted, autofocus did have some issues resolving under those light conditions, but it still managed to take good, sharp, pictures, despite being well outside of a "normal" use condition.
The video will only record for a little over 12 minutes, which is unfortunate, but it IS a "Still" camera. The microphone is actually pretty decent. I've managed to use it for at least 2 hours at a time, taking over a hundred photos, all using the screen on the back and the autofocus, which says something about the battery life. (Although, in that particular instance, I DID have the flash disabled, as I was trying to be respectful of others enjoyment of the event, so no flash might have saved a little battery,..but not as much as using the screen for a viewfinder must have cost.)

In short, I'm quite happy with mine, I would buy it again, and would heartily recommend it to anyone who was interested.

We bought this for our son, who has had an interest in learning more about photography. He really likes the different options on this camera, as well as the WiFI capability. There are lots of special effects and settings to try out, and since it's digital, if it doesn't work, it's easy to delete and try again. He thought he wanted an old school 35mm, but now he says he's glad he has a digital instead.

reviews.reviewTitle: SD Card format issues are common on this model
reviews.reviewText:
611/19 Update..the card functions great. So far so good!
6/6/19 Update: after researching I am finding this item to be a gray market item. There is a difference between the D and I version. Direct import vs Imported. This camera is a T6 1300D gray market. This is one of the reasons I am having a card issue. Page 5 of the manual indicates "this camera can use UHS 1 cards but since it is not comparable with the UHS 1 standard, reading/writing will be equivalent to SD Speed Class 10 at most." Amazon has an obligation to inform it's customer. I am hoping the SanDisk I ordered today will work. Otherwise the camera gets returned :0(

6/5/19 My camera will not format the SD card. Reading reviews online I'm trying to figure out if this is an international version and if that matters
100% in love with this camera. It is perfect for beginners and professionals. Amazing photos at long distances and close up.

Really great camera all around, especially for beginners. I definitely recommend buying this camera, it’s easy to use and takes amazing shots. just so you get a clear understanding of the quality, there will be photos below

reviews.reviewTitle: Cannon is a very nice camera, this camera has exceeded all expectations
reviews.reviewText: Cannon is a very nice camera, this camera has exceeded all expectations! It takes the best pictures and love the lens it comes with!

reviews.reviewTitle: At first I loved it but now I'm not so sure
reviews.reviewText: I like the two lenses that come with the set - it's very easy to change from lenses and both take really great pictures. However, the camera can be challenging to operate in anything other than automatic mode (I wouldn't call this a beginners camera). There are tons of different settings and the instruction manual is about 1/2 inch thick. Takes a lot of effort to figure out some of the more advanced features. My biggest complaint however is that the auto-focus function on the 18-55 mm lens has broken (less than 2 years after I bought the camera). I've seen this complaint on user boards and forums. Seems like pretty shoddy workmanship on an expensive device. I'm going back to Canon to see what resolution I can get and will update this post accordingly.

We purchased this camera to take on our 30 year class trip. It has been a great camera for us. My wife and I are beginners in photography and from the reviews we read, this looked like the right camera for us. The kit came with everything we needed to get started. I would recommend purchasing another battery.

I upgraded from an older, non-SLR Canon Rebel and I take a lot of youth soccer photos, but nothing professional. I found EOS Rebel T6 to be a nice step up from my previous model. I don't have to learn anything new and didn't have to shell out big bucks. It's perfect for what I use it for.
this camera's pictures are really not worth it... For the same price you can get a new phone with all the extra functionality and pics just as good

Extremely happy with this purchase. I bought this for my son and he has used it a bunch. Like that it came with the two lenses as that allows for a variety of photo opportunities. It appears to be very well constructed and we're still learning about all the features. Really like this camera. The packaging was well done and the shipment arrived in just a few days. Nice piece of equipment and fun!

reviews.reviewTitle: Don't buy on Amazon, go to a real camera store!
reviews.reviewText: I specifically wanted to purchase a brand new camera and received a refurbished camera. Sodisappointed. After a few photos the mirror stopped working. I'm returning and probably going to go with a different brand. Camera feels cheap as well.

Love my camera! Love everything about it! i needed a new camera for my family to take pictures on trips and or just for the holidays this is a great camera i don't know much but you tube is your friend when it comes to learning. pictures come out wonderful!

This is an excellent camera for beginners wanting to learn DSLR cameras. It provides automation that also allows for beginners to take photographs easily. This deal provides two lens both of which highly useful for photographs close in and far away. There is also the ability to add various Canon lens to extend that types of photos that can be taken. So this is a package that can grow with your abilities. I am well pleased with my purchase.

I like the data improvement from my last camera. I went from 1-3 MB to about 20-25MB. I plan to use the improved pixels to improve my art images for online sales and in applying to art contests. I haven’t used all of it’s features yet. I’m mostly using auto mode and a few of the manual modes, when I have time to think about the lighting, etc.

Bought this for my son a year ago for his 18th birthday...he has loved it since day one! The picture quality is beautiful and he learned this camera very fast! This was his first true camera that wasn’t a point and shoot. For the price, this is an excellent choice!

I'm a first time camera buyer/user and I absolutely love my Cannon T6. I did a lot of homework before buying and this was the brand and model that most appealed to me. It lived up to my expectations. The neck strap is not too comfortable but that's easily solved by changing it to maybe a cross body one like I did. The cam itself is very very good.

Exactly what my husband needed for his new camera! He was surprised and delighted. It came so quickly and was exactly as described. He is learning how to use it - and looking forward to posting his fishing pictures! Thank you.

Love love love this camera!
Great picture quality and love the fact that you can download an app on your phone and upload the picture from you camera directly to you phone.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easily one of best cameras to get started with DSLR
reviews.reviewText: Camera is great. WiFi connectivity is great, simple and advanced options are really good. Lenses are ok, probably good enough for entry level (all photos have come out better than expected). Was even able to use old lenses from Rebel SLR with ease. Highly recommend it.

The camera, so far so good. Right after I get it and start using it, I see the package deals being offered. I could have got a lot more for not much more money. Tripod, filters more lens wow. I know I can return it and all that, but I will look closer at all packaged deals in the future.

This is honestly a great quality camera for beginners with DSLRs. I learned how to use it super easily and the picture quality is great!! The app however is pretty crappy. Crashes too much so I'd recommend buying a cable to hook it up to your computer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best purchase I’ve made this year!
reviews.reviewText: I love my new camera, I love both lenses, they are easy for me as I am a beginner enthusiast. I need more time in the manual to figure out all the features but I’m impressed and very happy so far, so it can only get better from here!

reviews.reviewTitle: If I had it to do again, I wouldn't have bought (see pics)
reviews.reviewText:
Bottom line ... I was expecting something amazing. I got something okay. Without photoshop, you'd actually do better using a point and shoot or cell phone camera with auto image correction. On manual mode or auto mode, I still have yet to take a photo that looks better than one filtered on instagram.

So, I should start off by saying I am probably the prototype of the consumer this camera is marketed for. I have a great eye for photography. I've won a few photo contests and anyone who has ever seen my Instagram feed cannot believe a smartphone user took the photos I post. However, I know nothing about photography. To me ISO sounds like a ticker symbol for a stock and Aperture sounds like a night club in Miami. My purpose in buying this camera was to get something I could learn photography gradually on but still be able to use as a novice on auto-mode in the meantime.

The first thing I will say that I hate about this camera is that on auto-mode, the blue sky will almost always wash out to a white color completely, or it will look very unnatural with a light blue/white haze that contains gradient pixels upon closer inspection. I asked a friend to show me some settings outside of auto-mode which I could use in manual to make the sky look blue. I was told that 'white washing' a blue sky was a flaw that Canon cameras, specifically, were known for. And that it can be somewhat corrected in photoshop ... going to manual mode did not help correct this. Nothing more frustrating than going out on a beautiful, clear, blue sky California day and seeing washed out photos that make it look overcast. I've also noticed that it tends to wash out the sand in beach shots as well.

Another thing I hate about this camera is that perhaps the way the camera is designed, many of my pictures seem crooked. I thought at first that I would eventually get used to this and compensate for it automatically when taking a picture, yet the slight tilt still persists. I do have big hands and the camera does feel a bit small in my hands ... I wish they had some kind of a stock you could buy to make it feel more substantial but alas, there is none I can find. The camera does not feel like it sits in my hands comfortably and the fact that it is very lightweight and not at all heavy doesn't help things out. I am not quite sure what to do to stop pictures from coming out slightly crooked. I find that if I take my time when shooting, they will be straighter but if its a natural instinct where I need to get a quick shot and don't have time to think and compensate, the tilt is there.

The lighting is also an issue with this camera. My smartphone camera does better at shooting in low light than this camera. And when you use the flash indoors, it tends to illuminate an object in white, bright light making the subject look washed out and the background look darker. I am sure once I am able to shoot better in manual mode, I will figure out ways to shoot in lower lighting. However in auto-mode, it is almost useless to use this and I find myself instead reaching for my cell phone camera. That's pretty sad. I have been playing around with the shutter speeds after doing some research and haven't had much luck shooting in darker situations yet. It seems like the learning curve is pretty high but I am not giving up.

Be careful when using some of the 'semi-auto' settings ... I have found that using these modes gives you photos that look good on the little preview screen and then when I got back home and transferred them to the computer they were all blurry. What you see on the preview screen is not exactly what you will see on the large format picture from a computer monitor. Until you get out of auto mode into full-manual, I would be cautious about other settings. The same is true with auto-focus mode. While the photos you are taking may look clear on the small preview screen, they will likely be blurry and out of focus once you transfer them. The menus on this camera are not incredibly easy ... they are layered/stacked on top of each other and small buttons make it hard to navigate through them. Don't think you will pick this thing up and 'explore' your way around outside of auto-mode and easily learn. I feel like the old 35 mm cameras and their wheels and dials made things a lot more easy than on-screen menus which are layered on top of each other.

If you are doing portrait photography, you will want to pick up a 'nifty fifty' or a 50 mm lens. You will need to get a bit further away from your subject but it will give you the 'bokeh' look ... whereas the stock lenses will not give you the blurred background with the subject crisp and clear in the foreground. A friend of mine who is a professional photographer took it into manual mode and tried to get this look using the stock lens and could not. The zoom on this isn't all that great, so again, you will probably need to buy a lens for that as well. Very few of the telephoto lenses for Canon cameras at this level have image stabilization built in so its hard not to get blurry/chopping looking zoomed photos. Also, when using manual focus, it is hard to grasp the outside of the lens to turn the focus. I am much more comfortable with the focus being a band in the middle of the lens vs. the outer edge.

Perhaps the most glaring thing about this camera is its severe shutter lag. There are faster speeds you can use for sporting events, etc. in manual mode but until you have some area of expertise, those settings always come out blurry for me. To use auto-focus is painfully slow even in good lighting. Expect to wait a full 5 seconds sometimes before a photo will take! At times in auto focus mode, the camera will constantly re-focus and not take the photo. Either the lens will just keep whirling ... or there will be a little beeping sound indicating that the camera cannot find the focus and you cannot take the picture. This is often true in darker lighting, in situations where there might be movement (waves crashing, sunlight shining on water, cars going by, etc.) Again ... something that makes me go to my smartphone when I need a quick picture. The manual focus sometimes looks clear on the preview screen until you blow it up and see that it's blurry. Also, this camera has a lot of difficulty finding range ... meaning that its very hard with the stock lens to put subjects in the foreground and get them in focus without completely losing the background. Even in manual mode.

Overall, don't think this is a camera you will buy and be amazed with in manual mode. And don't think it will be easy to pick up and 'learn as you go' in manual mode. It's probably best to buy this if you plan on taking classes ... or if you have a friend who knows what they are doing and can teach you as you go. If that friend has a different make than a Canon, things get more difficult because the camera itself has different menus/settings. I maybe expected too much from the image quality. Even in manual mode, the pictures aren't as crisp and clear as I would like them to be. They look like pictures (even outside auto-mode) that you'd take with a point and shoot camera. This has showed me that until you get good at photography, there is no substitute for a $1,000+ camera. This is basically a point and shoot which has a lot more modes and features which help you learn photography.

I'm very disappointed with this camera based on my expectations. There is nothing professional about it but at the price point, I should have guessed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great camera for those on a budget!!
reviews.reviewText:
This camera is GREAT for a beginner. I’m currently in school for photography and had to upgrade to a dslr from a Nikon coolpix point and shoot. That camera was cool and has the same functions as my rebel but the quality is far better with it being a dslr. It is so amazing when you’re in a budget. I’m constantly getting told by classmates how amazing, clear and crisp my shots are.

There are going to be people complaining about the quality and the fact that the camera cannot do what they need it to. Well, if your picture quality sucks on auto that’s your fault. Switch to manual and learn your camera! Your pictures will be far better on manual. If you can’t do manual then shoot with aperture priority or shutter priority. This camera is fantastic and takes great pictures for a crop sensor. It’s not going to do what a full frame camera can do. It’s not. But for a crop sensor it’s pretty freaking amazing and takes fantastic pictures.

Also, the lens will not always give you crisp professional photos like you’d expect. It’s a kit lens and they don’t always take professional pictures but they can get the job done. I’ve taken great pictures with my kit lens. I even bought a 75-300 mm kit lens to explore. I don’t expect to get unbelievably amazing shots but I do know I can get some pretty dang good ones with it. Because I saved money on my camera body I was able to invest in a different lens other than the kit lenses. With this body and a better lens your picture quality will be even better! Get this camera, get a 50 mm prime lens and see how great your pictures look. That’s a great beginner lens on a budget. Get yungnuo it’s even cheaper than the one canon has. But with this body you can invest more in better lenses and when you do that man! This will bring yourbphotography level to a whole other level. I plan to buy more lenses that aren’t kit lenses and once I do I already know I’ll have some shots that’ll amaze everyone.

Photos were taken WITH my kit lens on manual saved on RAW not JPEG. See how great these are? For a beginner! Buy this camera!

reviews.reviewText:
I have owned Canon cameras all my life and recently received this DSLR one for Christmas. It’s my first camera of this kind. The carrying strap makes it even easier to carry. I am using a 32GB memory card and that allows for approximately 3,200 photos.

It was a tad difficult to find the video setting on the dial. Videos needed a bit of practicing as the first few came out blurry. This is the only minor downfall but with some practice the videos come out wonderful!

The battery life is wonderful and it’s easy to upload photos using WiFi! Gone are the days of cords to the computer (although it does come with cords in case you prefer that way!) I was very pleased with the apps that are available for free with it - wonderful and easy to use.

The package comes with the camera, two interchangeable lenses, a carrying strap, a carrying bag, cord to connect to computer, and manual.

Overall, this is a very easy to use camera for beginners. It offers professional quality photos with ease. Affordable option for a high end camera and the package is a great bargain! Definitely recommended!

reviews.reviewTitle: A great entry level DSLR - with a lot of flexibility and a wide range of wifi capabilities.
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using my EOS Rebel T6 for about two weeks now and have to say that it is a terrific base level DSLR. It offers the full flexibility of settings, with easy to navigate menus which allow easy access for quick changes during a session. The camera is equipped with both a traditional viewfinder and a spacious and colorful easy to read/view 3" LCD screen.
There is a broad selection of shooting resolution and format options - my preference is always to shoot in RAW at the highest quality setting, but you can shoot in JPEG format too with lower quality settings to conserve disk space. The 18MP sensor produces images with excellent detail and a wide color gamut.
This kit comes with two lenses - the standard 18-55mm and a 75-300mm for zooming in closer - I'd recommend getting a good wide angle lens to fill in the lower range, as the 18mm setting is a bit limiting. Both lenses will focus nicely, but it can take some time. They are not nearly as fast as the higher end Canon lenses. The 18-55mm lens is equipped with shake reduction, but it is only marginally reliable - so keep a steady hand, or tripod up!
There is a good range of ISO settings, but anything above 400 produces more noise than I like to see. (Revision: there are some excellent settings under the Custom Settings menu for dealing with noise both for long exposures, and/or ISO related. Its not a 100
% solution, but coupled with a good program like Photoshop, you can pretty much eliminate noise from your image without losing sharpness!)
This camera is wifi equipped - which means that you can connect wirelessly to upload images to a smartphone or tablet - it also means that, if you download the free Camera Connect app for IOS or Android, you can control your camera from the comfort of your mobile device. I like using my iPad because it gives me an enormous view surface, so I can really see what I'm shooting - and this more than makes up for the lack of an LCD swivel feature - you can control the camera and see your framing from almost anywhere in the shooting area. If you want to put yourself in the picture you can set up either a two or ten second delay - there is a flashing amber light onboard to give you a countdown!
The flash is basic popup.
The video quality is excellent too. Get yourself the biggest SD card you can afford if you plan to be doing any serious moviemaking.
The T6 gives you a lot of options as to how to make your settings. Most settings can be accomplished with buttons on the surface but you have the option of navigating the menu to get to them too.
A few minor issues I should mention. When shooting in continuous mode, I find that three shots is the max for efficiency. More than that and your camera starts giving you the "busy" signal between shots. When I fire off five shots, there is a minute or more wait while the camera clears the data.
If you are accustomed to using a small infrared remote, you are out of luck with this model. Remote shooting is done via mobile device or with a cable release.
The shutter sound is pretty loud so you might not want to use this one for concerts.
Overall, this is an excellent entry level DSLR. If you are moving up from Smartphone photography, or from a point and shoot digital its a great first step. You can shoot simply to start but have the luxury of custom settings when you are ready to learn to use the camera more efficiently.
I'd recommend a few spare batteries. The rechargeable made for this camera gives me about 300 shots on a charge - so for longer shoots I'm careful to bring a few spares with me.
It is amazing! 🙌🏾😵❄️️🤘🏾

reviews.reviewText: The camera is great, if it works. Mine came with a defective circuit board and wouldn't even turn on. I had to pay to ship the product back to Cannon for repair. Very pleased with this camera! It came promptly, and all pieces and everything I needed to get started shooting were in the box.

I purchased this for casual photography, I wanted to be able to take photos of my son that were better than smartphone quality, and this did just that. I wasn't so sure about jumping into getting a DLSR camera with no practice, but this really is quite easy to use once you spend some time playing around with it.
I chose this camera specifically for its wifi capabilities, I wanted to be able to instantly connect my photos to my smart phone and be able to edit there on the go if I so chose to. It connects like a dream, you DO have to download an app to get connectivity, but its simple to operate.
The 18-55mm Lens is a great starter, I have no complaints so far about using it to capture the photos I am wanting.

If you are on the fence about which camera to get, I recommend joining a Facebook group for the cameras you are interested in, or just a beginner photography group, and look at the photos posted there and see if they are the quality you are looking for.
Overall, Its the person behind the camera that will affect how they look in the end, but it gives you a good idea what to expect.

However, I would unequivocally recommend this camera if you are a beginner to using a DLSR camera.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Camera for a good price !!
reviews.reviewText: I was lucky enough to get a great deal on this kit (T6 base camera plus 2 lens, EF and EFS) for $299 (discount from Canon for $499 plus $200 from Frys Electronics). I got this new camera right after my old Rebel T2 stopped working down in June 2017 after many years. The T6 camera is great for any amateur who just wants to take great pictures or HD videos in auto mode. It also has advanced features available which I will rarely use. I played with the new WiFi features but found them difficult to handle. Most people just use cell phones to take pics and send them off anyway.

I bought this camera for my thirteen years old daughter, a budding photographer, to use for her yearbook staff. It is an excellent camera! She loves it and it takes great pictures and seems very easy to use.

I just got this camera yesterday and I already love it. It has a learning curve but the picture quality is a hundred times better than the cell phone I was using. Can't wait to take many more amazing pictures.

Canon really are being a bit naughty selling this camera with the old version of the standard zoom lens and not the latest STM model. Presumably they have a large stock of the older ones and decided to unload them with the EOS 1300D. This would put me off buying this overpriced camera, as the newer lens does not have a rotating front assembly and is a bit quieter and faster in operation.
